Creating is called karma. This chapter extensively clarifies this, thus it is called discrimination. Explaining this chapter's verse,
in general, three topics are addressed: first, clarifying the essence of karma; second, explaining the names of various karmas; third, miscellaneous
clarifications of various karmas.ğŸ”½In clarifying the essence of karma,
first, directly clarifying the essence of karma;
second, distinctions through various approaches;
third, extensively clarifying the manifest and unmanifest.ğŸ”½In directly clarifying the essence of karma,
first, clarifying the created karma;
second, clarifying the great elements that create.
In clarifying the created karma,
first, clarifying the two or three karmas;
second, clarifying the five kinds of karma.
Below this, the first clarifies the two or three karmas.
It raises questions by restating the previous [points].
The treatise states:
As explained above,ğŸ”½the world of sentient beings
and the world of the vessel,
each have many distinctions.
Such distinctions,
by what are they produced?
The verse states:
The distinctions in the world arise from karma, which is volition and what is produced by volition.
Thought is precisely the mental action, what is done refers to bodily and verbal [actions].
The explanation says:
The first sentence answers in general.ğŸ”½The next sentence clarifies the two actions.
The following two sentences clarify the three actions.
The world is differentiated by the arising of karma.
The differentiation of the world
is produced by karma.
It is not that the Lord of Self-Mastery and the Great BrahmÄ King
are the sole primary cause.
Acting as the cause of prior awakening,
they give rise to the various worlds.
Non-Buddhists conceive that the gods first give rise to the desire to contemplate,
desiring to enjoy objects.
This is called the cause of prior awakening, which can give rise to the world.
This is a false conception.
Karma has good and evil,
and the fruits are pure and defiled.
Among humans, good karma
is mixed with evil.
Because of mixed karma,
it causes the body to be impure.
It causes the external requisites
to be very delightful.
Among the gods, good karma
cannot be mixed with evil.ğŸ”½This is called pure karma.
Because the karma is purely good,
The inner and outer [results] that are aroused.
The two things are both wonderful. The question is: What is the nature of the karma that gives rise to this?
The answer is: Intention and what is done by intention.
This clarifies the two karmas.
In the sutras,
it is said that there are two karmas:
First, the karma of intention;
second, the karma after intention.ğŸ”½The karma after intention
refers to what is done by intention.
Intention is the mental karma, what is done refers to the physical and verbal karmas.
This clarifies the three karmas.
The previous two karmas
are divided into three types.
Intention is the mental karma.
What is done by intention
is the physical and verbal karmas.
Because they arise from intention,ğŸ”½they are called what is done by intention.
As for the mental karma,
it is established based on the instigator.
Karma is precisely intention.
It is associated with the mind.
It instigates the mind.
It is called mental karma.
As for the physical karma,
it is established based on the support.
The body refers to the physical body.
Karma arises based on the body.
It is called bodily action.
As for verbal action,
it is established based on its intrinsic nature.
Because the intrinsic nature of speech is itself action.
The treatise also says:ğŸ”½However, what is intended by the mindğŸ”½is precisely mental action.
The action that is intended
is called bodily and verbal action.
This is because it arises equally with intention. The commentary explains:
Intention is called arising equally.
Intention is equal to the mind
and can give rise to bodily and verbal actions.
From here is the second part.
It clarifies the five actions.
First, it clarifies the manifest and unmanifest.
Second, it clarifies bodily and verbal manifestations.
Third, it proves the existence of the unmanifest.
First, as for the first,
the manifest and unmanifest,
the treatise says:
As for the two actions of body and speech,
what is their intrinsic nature?
The verse says:ğŸ”½These two actions of body and speech
are both manifest and unmanifest by nature.
The commentary says:
Because there is both manifest and unmanifest in body and speech,
the two actions of body and speech are both manifest and unmanifest by nature.
From here is the second part.
Distinguishing bodily and verbal expressions.
The treatise first asks:
What are the characteristics of bodily and verbal expressions?
The verse says:
Bodily expression is considered to be a specific shape, not movement as its essence.ğŸ”½Because all conditioned dharmas
are momentary and perish,
there should be no cause, and the cause of arising should be able to destroy.
Shape also does not really exist, because it should be grasped by two sense organs.
Because there are no separate atoms, verbal expression is considered to be the sound of speech.
The commentary says:
The first nine lines clarify bodily karma.
The last line clarifies verbal karma.
The first line.
The treatise master explains the view of the SarvÃ¢stivÄda school.
Shape is considered bodily expression.
The next five lines.
The treatise master refutes the Saá¹ƒmitÄ«ya school's view that movement is bodily karma.
The next three lines.
The treatise master refutes the SarvÃ¢stivÄda school's view that shape and color really exist.
Bodily expression is considered to be a specific shape.
The SarvÃ¢stivÄda school.
Considers bodily karma.
Shape and color to be its essence.
Due to the power of thought.
It gives rise to such and such bodily forms.
This is called bodily expressive action.
Form refers to form-color.
It is like the form of joining palms, killing, binding, and so forth.
Form is precisely expression.
Because it expresses good and evil.
Expression is precisely action.
Because it has the function of creating.
This form-color arises based on the body.
Therefore, it is called bodily expressive action. It is not movement as its substance means
the Saá¹ƒmitÄ«ya school says
movement is called bodily expression.
In order to refute this,
it says not movement.
The Saá¹ƒmitÄ«ya school posits
that among conditioned dharmas,
mind and mental factors,
as well as sounds, lights, and so forth,
are admitted to be momentary and cease.
There definitely is no movement.
Bodily expressive form
is admitted to have movement,
so it does not cease in a moment.
When one bows to a Buddha and the body moves,
if the event has not yet ended,
this moving form does not cease in a moment.
When this body moves,
it expresses good or evil.
Therefore, bodily expressive action
has movement as its essence. Because all conditioned dharmas are momentary,
establishing the principle and directly refuting.
Because all conditioned dharmas are momentary,
there is definitely no movement.
How do we know they are all momentary?ğŸ”½Because they perish.
Since they perish later,
we know they cease earlier.
Therefore we know conditioned dharmas
all cease momentarily.
Therefore the two characters because they perish in the verse
explain the above because they are momentary.
The character because in the verse
is used twice.
Because they are momentary,
and because they perish.
This should be formulated as a logical argument:
Bodily expressive form
is the subject.
Definitely has no movement.
This is the property of the thesis.
The reason is:
Because it is momentary.
The example is:
Like mental factors and so forth.
All say:
Mental factors and so forth are momentary.
Mental factors and so forth have no movement.
Bodily expressive form is momentary.
Bodily expression has no movement.
Therefore the treatise says:
If it arises in this place,
it ceases in this place.
It is not possible for it to move from here to another place,
so it cannot be said that movement is called bodily expression.
That school argues:
We allow that bodily expression has no momentary cessation,
so there is movement.
This shows that the treatise master's reason of momentariness has the fault of inconclusiveness.
In order to refute this argument,
a logical argument should be established, saying:
Bodily expression and form definitely have moments,
because they have an end,
like mental factors and so forth.
All say:
Mental factors have an end later.
Mental factors have moments.
Bodily expression has an end later.
Bodily expression has moments.
Therefore, the two characters because they have an end
establish that all conditioned phenomena have moments.
That principle is extremely well-established.
Therefore the treatise says:
All conditioned phenomena
all have moments.
That principle is extremely well-established.
because it must be exhausted later.
It refers to conditioned dharmas.
Cessation does not depend on causes.
Why is this?
That which depends on causes is a result.
Cessation is not a result.
Therefore, it does not depend on causes. The commentary says:
Resultant dharmas depend on causes.
Cessation is a non-existent dharma.
A non-existent dharma is not a result.
Therefore, it does not depend on causes.
A logical argument should be established as follows:
Cessation does not depend on causes.
Because it is non-existent.
Just like the horns of a rabbit.
Since conditioned dharmas
cease without depending on causes,
it is clear that conditioned dharmas
all cease in a moment.
If there were no causeless cessation,
this refutes their further rescue.
They allow that the cessation of dharmas depends on causes for cessation.
Therefore, the treatise says:
Isn't it that firewood and so forth are seen in the world?
Due to combining with fire,
they cease without remainder.
There is definitely no other valid cognition that surpasses direct perception.
Therefore, the cessation of dharmas does not all occur without causes. Firewood ceases depending on fire.
This is precisely depending on causes.
Fuel, etc., are directly perceived by direct perception.
In order to refute this,
it says there should be no causelessness.
You accept that if fuel, etc., depend on causes to cease,
all cessation should not depend on causes.
Just as arising depends on causes and there is no causeless arising.
They all say:
Arisen dharmas depend on causes to arise.
There is no causeless arising.
Ceased dharmas depend on causes to cease.
There is no causeless cessation.
Directly perceiving the flames, etc.,
do not depend on causes to cease.
It is clearly known that the cessation of fuel, etc.,
also does not depend on causes to cease.
A syllogism should be established, saying:
Moreover, the cessation of fuel, etc.,
definitely does not depend on causes.
Because it is included in the conditioned.
Like flames, etc.
Flames are conditioned.
They cease without depending on causes.
Fuel, etc., are conditioned.
They also cease without depending on causes.
Mental factors and mental activities,
are collectively called mind.
Because they are able to perceive objects.
Flames refer to the flames of a lamp.
The arising cause should be able to extinguish.
Again, using principle to pursue it.
Moreover, if firewood, etc.,
combines with fire as the cause,
there is the arising of cooked transformation.
With distinctions of lower, middle, and upper.
Lower cooking is first yellow.
Middle cooking is next black.
Upper cooking is the darkest.
However, when middle cooking arises,
lower cooking is extinguished.
If upper cooking arises,
middle cooking is also extinguished.
The essence of the cause of upper cooking is precisely the extinction of the cause of lower and middle cooking.
Arising and extinguishing are contradictory.
How can the cause of arising be able to extinguish?
Therefore, using this principle,
it is shown that their establishment is not so.
The treatise says:
Therefore, there is no cause that causes dharmas to extinguish.
Dharmas naturally extinguish.
Because this is the nature of destruction.
Because of natural extinction,
as soon as they arise, they are extinguished.
Because as soon as they arise, they are extinguished,
the meaning of momentary extinction is established.
Because there is a moment,
There is definitely no movement. Bodily expression is established as shape through reasoning. Those who say that shape also does not really exist,
are of the SautrÄntika school.
They set forth the refutation of the SarvÃ¢stivÄda that shape really exists.
Therefore the treatise says:
However, the SautrÄntikas say:
Shape does not really exist.
It is said that an aggregation of visible form,
when many arise on one side,
is provisionally established as the color long.
In dependence on this color long,
in another aggregation of color, when few arise on one side,
it is provisionally established as the color short. When many arise on all four sides,
it is provisionally established as the color square.
When it arises completely filling all places, it is provisionally established as the color round.
The remaining shapes
should be understood accordingly. The remaining shapes
such as high, low, etc.
are all provisionally established.
When one sees a firebrand on one side,
moving quickly without interruption,
one takes it to be long.
When one sees it turning around,
one takes it to be the color round.
Therefore shape does not have a real substance of a separate type of form.
Because it should be grasped by two faculties.
This is the correct reasoning established by the SautrÄntika to refute the VaibhÄá¹£ika.
You, the VaibhÄá¹£ika,
if you say that there really exists a separate type of shape-color,
then there would be the fault of one color being grasped by two faculties.
Just like long and other colors,
one eye faculty sees them,
and two body faculties touch them.
Because when the body touches them, one knows their length and shortness.
Because of this, there would be the fault of being grasped by two faculties.
Among the twelve sense bases,
rationally there is no form base that is grasped by two faculties.
Therefore, one should know that shape-color
originally has no real substance.
The treatise says:
However, just as one grasps the characteristics of length, etc. based on touch,
in the same way, one can grasp shape based on manifestation.
This passage is the correct principle established by the SautrÄntika.
As for based on touch,
because shape is a conceptual construct,
when the body faculty touches it,
the mental consciousness, in the middle of that,
based on the body faculty's touch,
grasps the conceptual constructs of length, etc.
Therefore, it is said to be based on touch.
This is precisely the mental consciousness.
Based on the body faculty's touch,
Taking long, etc.
Because there are no separate atoms.
This explains the reason for positing shape as nominal.
That is to say, apart from the manifest colors,
there are no separate atoms called long, etc.
But by the manifest colors,
arranged in this way,
within the characteristics of the differences,
the characteristics of long, etc., square, etc. are provisionally established.
This is called the difference in names.
However, in the SautrÄntika school,
shape is bodily expression.
It is only nominal, not real.
Although shape is expression,
it is not action.
As for bodily action,
it takes volition as its essence.
That is to say, the volition that variously moves the body,
acting through the door of the body,
is called bodily action.ğŸ”½Because it is the action of the body,
it is called bodily action.
As for verbal action,
it also takes volition as its essence.
That is to say, the volition that gives rise to speech,
acting through the door of speech,
is called verbal action.ğŸ”½Because it is the action of speech,
it is called verbal action.
As for mental action,
Namely, the thought of careful consideration,
and the thought of determination.
They are the essence of mental action.
Therefore, these three actions
all have thought as their essence.
Following the different gates,
the distinctions are established.
Acting through the gate of mind,
it is called mental action.
Acting through the gate of body,
it is called bodily action.
Acting through the gate of speech,
it is called verbal action.
In total there are four thoughts:
First, the thought of careful consideration,
second, the thought of determination,
third, the thought of moving the body,
fourth, the thought of emitting and realizing.
The first two are mental actions,
the third is bodily action,
and the fourth is verbal action.ğŸ”½Because in the SautrÄntika school, the two bodily and verbal expressions
are dull in nature,
they are only indeterminate.
They are not the same as the two bodily and verbal actions of the SarvÃ¢stivÄda school,
which take form as their essence.
Bodily action is bodily form,
and verbal action is sound.
They are both categorized as form.
Therefore the treatise says:
It refers to the preparatory stage,
where one gives rise to the thought of consideration.
I should do such and such.
The things that should be done.
Is called the karma of thinking.
Having contemplated like this.
Arise to do the karma of thinking.
That is, according to what one contemplates, one does what should be done.
Capable of giving rise to body and speech.
Is called the karma of having thought.
The SautrÄntika interpretation of the two karmas in the sÅ«tra.
Wishes to clarify that the two karmas.
Are all of the nature of thinking.ğŸ”½Thinking of means.
That is, the thinking of careful consideration.
And the thinking of determination.
Speech expression is acknowledged as the sound of words.

That is, the sound of words is the karma of speech expression.
This bodily and verbal karma.
All have no expression.
As previously analyzed and concluded in the chapter on realms.
From here, third.
Certifying the existence of no expression.
As in the chapter on realms.
Because the SautrÄntika school does not acknowledge no expression as truly existent.
They say that no expression.
Is merely the seeds of thinking.
That is, the actualized thinking of careful consideration, determination, and movement.
On the basis of form and mind,
perfuming produces seeds.
On this seed of thought,
preventing evil and stopping wrongdoing,
the hypothetical non-manifest is established.
But simply not doing evil,
is called the non-manifest.
There is no real substance.
Therefore the treatise says:
The SautrÄntika school also says:
This does not really exist.
Because of the prior vow,
only not doing is the reason.
They also establish it based on past primary elements.
However, past primary elements,
are not existent in substance.
Moreover, all non-manifestations are without form. The commentary says:
First, by not doing,
it is called the non-manifest.
Second, the non-manifest
is based on past primary elements.
The primary elements are not even existent,
how could the non-manifest exist?
Third, moreover, it is without form.
For these three reasons,
therefore the non-manifest has no reality.
Therefore, from here on,
the SarvÃ¢stivÄda school,
uses eight meanings to prove that the non-manifest really exists.
The verse says:
It is said that there are three kinds of pure form, because of the increase of merit, non-action, etc.
The commentary says:
This verse has eight proofs.
First, the proof of the statement of three kinds of form.
Second, the proof of the statement of pure form.
Third, the proof of the increase of merit.
Fourth, the proof of non-action and the performance of karma.
Fifth, the proof of form in the dharma realm.
Sixth, the proof of the eightfold noble path.
Seventh, the proof of the precepts of individual liberation.
Eighth, the proof of the precepts as a dike and embankment.
As for it is said that there are three kinds of pure form,
this brings up two proofs.
First, the proof of the statement of three kinds of form.
Second, the proof of the statement of pure form. As for because of the increase of merit, non-action, etc.,
Increase refers to the third proof of the increase of merit.
Non-action refers to the fourth proof of non-action and the performance of karma.
The other four proofs are included in the word etc. As for the first proof of the statement of three kinds of form,
it is because a sutra states that form is of three kinds.
These three serve as the basis.
They encompass all forms.
The first is the form realm, which is visible and has resistance.
Second, there are forms that are invisible but have resistance, such as the five sense faculties of the eye, etc.
Sound, smell, taste, and touch.
Third, there are forms that are invisible and have no resistance, such as the unmanifest form.
Since this sÅ«tra speaks of forms that are invisible and have no resistance,ğŸ”½it is clear that unmanifest form definitely exists.
The second proof using undefiled form is as follows.
As a sÅ«tra says:
What are the undefiled dharmas?
It refers to all forms in the past, future, and present.
One does not give rise to desire or aversion.
Up to consciousness, it is the same.ğŸ”½This is called the undefiled dharma.
Since this sÅ«tra speaks of undefiled form,
it is clear that unmanifest form
must definitely have a real substance.
Apart from unmanifest form,ğŸ”½there is no other form that can be called undefiled.
The third proof using the increase of merit is as follows.
As a sÅ«tra says:
Those who have pure faith,
whether good sons or good women,
accomplish the seven meritorious activities that rely on form.
Whether walking or standing still,
Whether asleep or awake,
continuously and uninterruptedly,
meritorious karma continues to arise.
The same is true for the unaffiliated.
Since this sÅ«tra says that meritorious karma increases,
meritorious karma increases,
which is precisely the unmanifest.
It means that after the donor has given a gift,
he may give rise to an evil mind or a neutral mind,
or when he is without thought.
If there were no unmanifest,
on what basis would it be said that meritorious karma increases?
Therefore, we know that the unmanifest
truly has a substance.
The seventh is meritorious karma with a basis.ğŸ”½The first is giving to travelers on the road.
The second is giving to those traveling on the road.ğŸ”½The third is giving to the sick.
The fourth is giving to those who care for the sick.
The fifth is giving gardens and groves.
The sixth is giving to those who always beg for food.
The seventh is giving according to the season.
These seven kinds
are good, so they are called meritorious.
Because they are created, they are called karma.
Karma relies on these seven,
so they are called affairs.
The eighth is meritorious karma without a basis.
It is giving without possessions.
But if one gives rise to a profound mind,
and joyfully accepts and respectfully practices it,ğŸ”½one will also give rise to supreme blessings.
Fourth, as for the evidence of non-manifest karma,
if one does not do it oneself,
but sends others to kill and so forth,
if there is no non-manifest karma,
it should not constitute a karmic path.
The reason for this is as follows.
It refers to initiating speech and issuing orders,
sending others to kill and so forth.
This initiating speech and expression,
is not included in the karmic paths.
Because the messenger has not yet committed killing and so forth.
If the messenger
has finished killing and so forth,
this previous speech and expression
has no different nature.
How can the one who gives the order
complete the karmic path of killing and so forth?
It is clear that there is a separate non-manifest karma of killing and so forth,
that enters the body.
Therefore, the one who gives the order can complete the karmic path.
Therefore, this karmic path
is included in the non-manifest karma.
Fifth, as for the evidence of form in the dharma realm,
it is also said in the sutra:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that.
Dharma refers to the external sense bases.
These are the eleven sense bases.
The dharmas not included in these.
Are invisible and unimpeded.
This sÅ«tra, within the sense base of dharmas,
Does not mention formless [dharmas].
Therefore, we know that within the sense base of dharmas,
There truly are unmanifest forms.
If there were no unmanifest forms,
This sÅ«tra would be incomplete.
And would become useless.
Because the sÅ«tra would be incomplete, not mentioning formless [dharmas].
Since it does not say there are no formless [dharmas],
We clearly know that unmanifest [forms] truly exist.
Sixth, as for the evidence of the eight factors of the path,
If there were no unmanifest [karma],
There would be no eight factors of the path.
Because, among the eight factors of the path,
Right speech,ğŸ”½Right action,
And right livelihood,
These three are unmanifest [karma].
Therefore, the treatise says:
Because there is no speech, etc., during concentration. The commentary explains:
In concentration, one cannot speak,
So there is no right speech.
The body does not move, such as performing prostrations to the Buddha, so there is no right action.
Not begging for food, etc., so there is no right livelihood.
Since, within concentration,
The three of right speech and so on are explained.
Because they are in concentration.
There is right speech and so on.
The three kinds of unmanifest form.
After coming out of concentration.
One is able to give rise to the three rights.
One does not give rise to the three wrongs.
Therefore, in concentration.
Right speech and so on are explained.
This is because the name of the effect is established on the basis of the cause.
The cause is the unmanifest form.
The effect is right speech and so on. The seventh proof of the precepts of individual liberation.
If there were no unmanifest form.
Then there would also be no precepts of individual liberation.
Because after receiving the precepts, although one gives rise to thoughts of evil or indeterminate objects,
One is still called a bhiká¹£u.
It is clear that there is a separate unmanifest form of precepts.
Called the precepts of individual liberation.
Among evil and indeterminate states.
It continues to evolve.
Called a bhiká¹£u and so on.
The eighth proof of the precepts as a dike and embankment.
Moreover, the scriptures say.
The precepts that depart from killing and so on.
Are called the precepts as a dike and embankment.
They are able to continue for a long time.
Because it restrains and prevents transgressions of precepts.
Since this sÅ«tra says that precepts are like dikes and embankments,
it is clear that there is a separate form of unmanifest precepts.
The SarvÄstivÄda school.
Cites the above eight proofs.
To prove that unmanifest [karma] is real. From here, the SautrÄntika school.
Unifies the previous explanations.
First, the three kinds of form.
Are the form of meditative objects.
Not the form of unmanifest [karma].
Yoga means corresponding.
It refers to the correspondence between mind and objects. The teacher says.
When cultivating meditative concentration.
The form generated by the power of concentration.

Based on the pure meditative concentration.

called increasing merit.

Always continuous,
merit gradually increases.

One perfuming,
two subtleties,

The fifth, the form included in the dharma realm,
is the form of the object of concentration mentioned above.
The sixth, the eight branches of the noble path,
the treatise says:
Although there is no unmanifest [form],
at the time of being on the path,
one attains such
a mind, aspiration, and basis.
Therefore, after emerging from contemplation,
by the power of the previous [path],
It can give rise to the three correct [courses of action],
and does not give rise to the three incorrect [courses of action].
This is because in the cause, the name of the effect is established.
It can be fully established as the eight branches of the noble path.
According to the SautrÄntika school,
the intention that occurs simultaneously with the path,
is called intention.
It serves as the basis for the three correct [courses of action] after emerging from concentration.
Therefore, it is called basis.
The intention that occurs simultaneously with the path,
is provisionally established as unmanifest.
It is called the unmanifest that occurs simultaneously with the path.
The unmanifest has no substance.
On the basis of this intention,
the correct speech and so forth are established.
The rest of the text can be understood. The seventh is the precepts of individual liberation.
It also takes the seeds of intention as its essence.
On the basis of the seeds of intention,
there is the ability to prevent wrongdoing and stop faults.
It provisionally establishes the unmanifest.
Therefore, the treatise says:
That is to say, by the power of intention and vow,
one first establishes a binding commitment that can definitely restrain and prevent evil bodily and verbal actions.
For this reason, the precepts of individual liberation are established. The treatise says above. The eighth,
As for precepts being like embankments and dikes,
the treatise says:
It means first establishing a vow and limit,
definitely not doing evil.
